title-group.article-title: Enhancing tensile and compressive strengths of magnesium using nanosize (Al2O3 + Cu) hybrid reinforcements

abstract.p: This study investigates the microstructure and mechanical properties of magnesium (Mg) containing alumina (Al2O3) and copper (Cu) nanoparticles as hybrid reinforcements. For composite preparation, the amount of Cu was varied from 0.1 to 0.9 volume percent, whereas the amount of Al2O3 was fixed at 1 volume percent. Mg and its composites were synthesized using powder metallurgy route incorporating energy-efficient microwave sintering followed by hot extrusion. Hybrid reinforcements in Mg matrix led to a grain size reduction, and the grain size decreased with increasing presence of secondary phases (reinforcements and intermetallics). Overall distribution of secondary phases within the matrix was observed to be uniform despite the formation of clusters. A significant improvement in microhardness was exhibited by all composite formulations when compared to pure Mg. The results also showed that yield and ultimate strengths were enhanced in all composite formulations under both tensile and compressive loading while tensile and compressive failure strains were compromised.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Metal matrix composites (MMCs) are evolving as a new class of materials for diverse engineering applications for almost three decades now.1,2 The requirement of high-performance light-weight materials in various energy savvy applications demanded for the fabrication of MMCs based on light metal matrices. Magnesium (Mg) is the lightest of all metallic materials and possesses the highest strength-to-density ratio. Studies were done on Mg-based composites as potential structural materials due to their ability to exhibit low-density, good mechanical properties, high wear resistance and low thermal expansion. Ceramic reinforcements, typically alumina (Al2O3), silicon carbide (SiC), and boron carbide, are commonly used in Mg matrix to fabricate Mg-based composites.2–4 In some studies, research efforts were made to synthesize Mg composites using metal particle reinforcements.5–9 Investigations were also made on the Mg composites containing hybrid reinforcements in the form of ceramic + metal, ceramic + ceramic and ceramic + CNT besides single ceramic, metal, and CNT reinforcements.10–16 Previous studies have indicated that the strength and/or ductility of pure Mg can be improved through the addition of nano length scale reinforcements either in the form of single17–21 or hybrid10–14 reinforcements. Reinforcements used in the composites are normally in the form of as-received powder particles. Recently, Habibi et al. reported the mechanical property improvement in Mg using ball-milled Al + Al2O322 and Al + CNT23 reinforcements in which micron-size Al was hybridized with nano length scale reinforcements (Al2O3 and CNT). However, the effect of nano size hybrid reinforcements in ball-milled form has not been investigated in the open literature. Accordingly, this study attempted to synthesize Mg nanocomposites containing ball-milled ceramic and metal particles (Al2O3 + Cu) in which both Al2O3 and copper (Cu) are in nano size. The choice and amount of Al2O3 and Cu as hybrid reinforcements were derived thoughtfully from the previous studies8,19 in which the addition of individual reinforcement in Mg led to enhanced mechanical properties in related composite systems.

Composites were prepared using powder metallurgy route followed by hot extrusion. The amount of Al2O3 was fixed at 1 volume percent and the amount of Cu was varied from 0.1 to 0.9 volume percent to produce various composite compositions. Investigations were made on the microstructure and mechanical property changes in composites due to the presence of hybrid reinforcements containing different amount of Cu. Due to its enhanced mechanical properties, the synthesized composites look promising for automobile and aerospace applications in which their possible use could be in roof components, seat frame, seat arm support, rudder pedal assembly, etc.24,25

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: In this study, commercial Mg powder (Mg ≥ 98.5%, Fe ≤ 0.05% and substances insoluble in hydrochloric acid ≤0.05%) with a particle size of 60–300 µm (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany) is used as matrix material. Al2O3 with an average particle size of 50 nm (Baikowski, Chiba-ken, Japan) and Cu with an average particle size of 25 nm (Nanostructure and Amorphous Materials Inc., Los Alamos, NM) are used as particulate reinforcements.

sec.title: Reinforcement preparation
sec.p: Hybrid reinforcements with various proportions of Al2O3 and Cu (fixed amount of 1 volume percent Al2O3 was mixed with 0.1, 0.3, 0.6 and 0.9 volume percent of Cu) were prepared using ball milling method. Stearic acid was used as process control agent (PCA) during ball milling. Al2O3 and Cu particles were initially blended with 0.3 wt.% stearic acid for 1 h using Retsch PM-400 plenary ball milling machine. The steel balls were then added into the blended powder mixture and the ball-to-powder ratio used was 20:1. Ball milling was done for 2 h and the speed of the machine was set at 200 rpm during blending and ball milling processes.

sec.title: Primary processing
sec.p: After completing ball milling, pure Mg powder and ball-milled reinforcement mixtures were weighed in accordance with the designated proportions in an argon-filled glove box. The powder mixtures (Mg and ball-milled reinforcements) were then blended at 200 rpm for 1 h using Retsch PM-400 plenary ball milling machine. No balls or PCAs were used during blending. The blended powder mixtures were then uniaxially cold compacted at a pressure of 97 bars (50 t) to form billets of 35-mm diameter and 40-mm height using a 100-t press. Monolithic Mg was compacted using the same parameters without ball milling or blending. The compacted billets were sintered using microwave-assisted hybrid sintering technique for 14 min to attain a temperature of ∼640°C in a 900 W, 2.45 GHz SHARP microwave oven using SiC as the microwave susceptor material. This hybrid heating method results in a more uniform temperature gradient within the billet and circumvents the disadvantage of heating using either conventional heating or microwaves only.

sec.title: Secondary processing
sec.p: The sintered billets of pure Mg and its composites were coated with colloidal graphite and soaked at 400°C for 1 h. The billets were then subsequently hot extruded at a temperature of 350°C with an extrusion ratio of 25:1 to produce 7-mm diameter extruded rods.

sec.title: Density measurements
sec.p: The density of the extruded Mg and Mg nanocomposites in the as-polished condition was measured using Archimedes’ principle. Three samples were randomly selected from the extruded rods and were carefully weighed both in air and when fully immersed in distilled water. AND ER-182A electronic balance with an accuracy of 0.0001 g was used for recording the weights. The theoretical densities of composite samples were calculated using rule-of-mixtures. For computing theoretical densities of composites, density values of 1.74 g/cc for Mg, 3.98 g/cc for Al2O3, and 8.94 g/cc for Cu were used.

sec.title: Microstructural characterization
sec.p: Microstructural characterization studies were conducted to determine grain size, grain morphology, presence and distribution of reinforcements and intermetallics. Olympus metallographic optical microscope, Scion Image Analyzer and HITACHI S-4300 Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FESEM) were used for this purpose.

sec.title: X-ray diffraction studies
sec.p: X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out on the polished extruded Mg and Mg nanocomposite samples using automated Shimadzu LAB-X XRD-6000 diffractometer. The samples were exposed to CuKα radiation (λ = 1.54056Å) at a scanning speed of 2°C/min. The Bragg angle and the values of the interplanar spacing (d) obtained were subsequently matched with the standard values for Mg, Al2O3, Cu and related phases.

sec.title: Mechanical behavior
sec.p: The mechanical behavior of both monolithic and composite samples was quantified in terms of microhardness, tensile and compressive properties. Microhardness measurements were performed on the polished samples using Shimadzu-HMV automatic digital microhardness tester. The microhardness test was performed using a Vickers indenter under a test load of 25 gf and a dwell time of 15 s in accordance with the ASTM standard E384-99.

The tensile properties of the as-extruded monolithic Mg and its composite counterparts were determined in accordance with procedures outlined in ASTM standard E8M-01. The tensile tests were conducted on round tension test specimens (5-mm gage diameter and 25-mm gage length) on a fully automated MTS 810 servo-hydraulic mechanical testing machine at a crosshead speed set at 0.254 mm/min.

Room temperature compressive tests were performed on cylindrical monolithic and composite samples according to ASTM E9-89a using an automated MTS 810 servo hydraulic testing machine. Extruded rod of 7-mm diameter was cut into 7-mm length samples for compression tests to provide the aspect ratio (l/d) of unity. Samples were tested at a strain rate of 8 × 10−5 s−1 and the compression load was applied parallel to the extrusion direction. The stress versus strain curves obtained following testing were used to compute the work of fractures (area under the engineering stress versus engineering strain curve) using an excel software.

sec.title: Density and grain size
sec.p:
It can be seen from Table 1 that the experimental densities were very close to the theoretical densities in both monolithic and composite samples. This indicates that highly dense Mg and Mg composites can be synthesized using the current processing method of microwave-assisted powder metallurgy route followed by hot extrusion. Achieving high density also indicates the lower amount of porosity level in the synthesized materials. This is supported by the results of porosity computation (Table 1) where the amount of porosity in both monolithic and composite samples was found to be below 1 volume percent. Grain size measurement results (Table 1) revealed a reduction in average grain size with the increasing presence of hybrid (Al2O3 + Cu) reinforcements in Mg matrix (Figure 1). This indicates that the addition of Cu clearly supported the grain refinement mechanisms in the composites because the amount of Al2O3 was fixed at 1 volume percent. The resultant grain refinement in the composites can primarily be attributed to the presence of second phases (Al2O3, Cu and Mg2Cu intermetallics) and their ability to effectively pin the grain boundaries. The use of Cu as hybrid reinforcement has an ability in grain size reduction because of the combined effects of Mg2Cu intermetallics formation (Figure 2) and in assisting recrystallization of matrix grains. Similar observation was also reported in the previous studies.8,11 In accordance with Mg-Cu phase diagram,29 Cu has low solubility in Mg and the formation of Mg-Cu intermetallics is limited (Figure 2). The decreasing trend in average grain size with increasing presence of Cu in the composites can be attributed to increased nucleation source for recrystallization induced by elemental Cu. The above hypothesis is supported by the microstructural observation shown in Figure 1. Through the addition of Cu from 0.1 to 0.6 volume percent (Figure 1(a)–(c)) to Mg/1volAl2O3 composition, we can see that the occurrence of small grains was associated with the region where aggregated Cu phases were essentially present. On the other hand, the larger grains were observed in the region lacking secondary phases. In case of Mg/(1volAl2O3 + 0.9volCu) composition, Cu aggregates were predominantly observed (Figure 1(d)). The Cu phases were mostly in aggregated form and matrix grains were quite similar and smaller in size (see also Table 1). This indicates that stimulation of recrystallization was induced by Cu and its phases. From the related studies, it was reported that the use of micron length scale reinforcements can provide effective grain refinement via particulate-stimulated nucleation.30,31 The same concept could apply in this study based on the observation of micron-size Cu aggregates which can provide as a nucleation source for recrystallization of matrix grains. On the other hand, Al2O3 reinforcement could not have the ability in supporting the recrystallization process because of nano length scale particle size. A critical particle size of about 1–2 µm is required for the occurrence of the particle-stimulated nucleation.32,33 The previous studies31,33 reported that fine and closely spaced particles of <0.1 µm in size can even retard the recrystallization. Due to the size difference between Mg matrix and Al2O3 reinforcement, it is a common phenomenon that most of the Al2O3 particles will be located at the grain boundary, thereby taking part in the grain growth restriction. However, the extent of restriction depends on the location and amount of Al2O3 particles added in the composites.34 Figure 1.

sec.title: XRD analysis
sec.p: Figure 2 shows the XRD pattern of pure Mg and its composites. XRD results revealed that Cu phase was detected in all composite formulations. This indicates that Cu remained in the composites in pure elemental form due to coupled reasons of its limited solid solubility in Mg and short sintering time limiting the formation of intermetallic phases. In all composite samples, Al2O3 phase was not detected in the XRD profile. Mg2Cu intermetallic phase was detected only in the case of Mg/(1volAl2O3 + 0.9volCu) composite composition. The absence of Al2O3 and Mg2Cu intermetallic peaks in composites can be attributed to (a) fine particulate/intermetallic size, (b) presence of very low amount of intermetallic phases, and (c) minimal or lack of aggregated particulate/intermetallic phases.

sec.title: Microstructure
sec.p:
The typical distribution of secondary phases in Mg matrix is shown in Figure 3. It can be seen from the micrographs that relatively uniform distribution of the second phases was achieved in all synthesized composites. Within composite formulations, more uniform and finely dispersed second phases were observed in Mg/(1volAl2O3 + 0.6volCu) composite (Figure 3(c)). Although the amount of Cu increases from 0.1 to 0.6 volume percent in Mg/1volAl2O3 composition, increasing number of second phase clusters was observed instead of larger size clusters. In case of Mg/(1volAl2O3 + 0.9volCu) composite, however, the cluster size was relatively larger although the clusters were still well distributed (Figure 3(d)). Figure 3.

sec.title: Microhardness
sec.p:
The results of microhardness measurements are shown in Table 2. With the addition of hybrid (Al2O3 + Cu) reinforcements into Mg matrix, an increase in microhardness was observed in all composite compositions when compared to that of monolithic Mg. Also, the increment follows with increasing amount of Cu up to 0.6 volume percent addition to Mg/1vol Al2O3 composition. However, a decrease in hardness value was observed when the amount of Cu increases from 0.6 to 0.9 volume percent. Hardness improvement in all composite formulations when compared to pure Mg can generally be attributed to (a) grain refinement, (b) the presence of second phases (Al2O3, Cu and Mg2Cu intermetallics) in Mg matrix and (c) constraint of matrix deformation due to the presence of the second phases. A peak hardness value was observed at a composition of Mg/(1vol Al2O3 + 0.6volCu) composite composition. This can be explained by the evidence of well-distributed second phases in the micrograph shown in Figure 3(c). To achieve high hardness level in composites, clustering of second phases is not preferable due to a number of facts, including larger intercluster spacing and pore formation at the clustered particles region which contributes to lowering of matrix hardness. In case of Mg/(1volAl2O3 + 0.9volCu) composite composition, the hardness was decreased when compared to Mg/(1volAl2O3 + 0.6volCu) composition. This can primarily be attributed to the larger and widely spaced second phase clusters as can be seen in the micrograph in Figure 3(d). Table 2.

sec.title: Tensile properties
sec.p:
The results obtained from room temperature tensile test are shown in Table 2 and the representative tensile curves are shown in Figure 4. The addition of (Al2O3 + Cu) hybrid reinforcements in monolithic Mg led to an improvement in tensile yield and ultimate strengths in all composite compositions, whereas the tensile failure strain was found to decrease. However, at an optimum composite composition of Mg/(1volAl2O3 + 0.6volCu), only a marginal reduction in failure strain was observed together with a significant improvement in tensile yield and ultimate strengths. An improvement in yield and tensile strengths in all composite formulations when compared to pure Mg can generally be attributed to well-known strengthening mechanisms via (a) Hall-Petch relationship due to grain refinement, (b) Orowan strengthening due to the presence of fine reinforcement/intermetallic phases, (c) elastic and coefficient of thermal expansion mismatch between matrix and reinforcements and (d) effective load transfer from matrix to second phases. On the other hand, the failure strain tends to decrease in composites when compared to pure Mg. From the micrographs shown in Figure 3, the formation of clusters was observed with the addition of hybrid reinforcements in Mg matrix irrespective of the amount of Cu. In case of Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.6 vol Cu) composite composition, the distribution of the second phases was found to be uniform together with fine (compared to other composite compositions) and relatively discontinuous second phase clusters (Figures 1(c) and 3(c)). The observation of homogenous microstructure in relation to the uniform second phase distribution and grain refinement translates to the best failure strain when compared to other composite formulations (Table 2). In case of Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.1 vol Cu) and Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.3 vol Cu), the presence of second phases in mostly continuous form and less uniformity in grain size (Figure 1(a) and (b)) could be the reason for the resultant reduction in failure strain.35,36 In case of Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.9 vol Cu) composite composition, the presence of large clusters (a few micron in size) and the continuous form of these clusters (Figures 1(d) and 3(d)) could be the prime factor for inferior failure strain obtained from the tensile test results (Table 2). Like in composites containing micron-size particles,2 the current composite composition, Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.9 vol Cu), follows the trend of achieving high strength with a significant compromise in ductility. sec.title: Compressive properties
sec.p:
The room temperature compressive properties of the synthesized materials are shown in Table 3, and the related compression curves are shown in Figure 5. Both compressive yield strength and ultimate compressive strength were increased with increasing amount of Cu in Mg/1 vol Al2O3 composition except for the addition of 0.9 volume percent Cu in which ultimate compressive strength decreased. When compared to monolithic Mg, the strengths were improved whereas a compromise in compressive failure strain was observed in all composite compositions. The best combination of compressive strength and failure strain was exhibited by Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.6 vol Cu) composite. The increase in compressive yield strength in case of composites with an increasing amount of Cu can be attributed to a progressive reduction in grain size and increase in number of second phase clusters (Table 1, Figures 1 and 3). The ultimate compressive strength also improved with an increase in amount of Cu up to 0.6 volume percent into Mg/1 vol Al2O3 composition. A reduced ultimate compressive strength when compared to Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.6 vol Cu) composite composition but higher compressive strength when compared to the rest two composite compositions, Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.1 vol Cu) and Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.3 vol Cu), was observed in Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.9 vol Cu) composite formulation (Table 3). The observed compression test results indicate that the presence of coarse second phases and fine grain size favorably enhances strengths in composites under compressive loading. On the other hand, a compromise in compressive failure strain was observed in all composite compositions when compared to that of Mg. Compressive failure strain in all composites was statistically similar and independent of the amount of Cu reinforcement. This indicates that the compressive failure strain was not affected by the microstructural changes. Under compressive loading, twinning is the most favorable deformation mode for Mg. In case of pure Mg, the activity and propagation of twinning is favorable without any disturbance such as due to the presence of secondary phases and also due to coarse grain size. In case of composites, twin activation and propagation could be difficult due to obstacles provided by secondary phases and grain refinement. Easy twin activation/nucleation can be accounted for the yielding of pure Mg at low strength and that of composites at high strength is associated with delayed twin activation/nucleation. The effortless twin propagation led pure Mg to exhibit higher failure strain. In composites, twin propagation was resisted by barriers like second phases and increased number of grain boundaries. Consequently, the composites failed at lower failure strain when continuity of twinning ceases. The resultant failure mechanisms in pure Mg and its composites are fundamentally in agreement with observations from the previous studies.13,14 Figure 5.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The main conclusions that can be drawn from the present investigation are as follows:
The computed porosity levels in the powder metallurgy processed Mg and its composites were below 1 volume percent. This indicates the ability of microwave-assisted powder metallurgy method combined with hot extrusion to fabricate near dense Mg-based composites.
The size of matrix grains reduced due to the addition of hybrid (Al2O3 + Cu) reinforcements in Mg. A decreasing trend of grain size with increasing presence of Cu in Mg/1 vol Al2O3 was observed in the composites. This can primarily be attributed to the recrystallization of matrix grains stimulated by Cu and its phases.
Cu peak was detected through XRD analysis on all composites samples, indicating that Cu remained in its elemental form in composites to a reasonable extent.
Microstructural observation revealed reasonable second phase distribution throughout Mg matrix in all composite formulations. Formation of clusters was observed in all composite formulations.
Mechanical testing results showed a significant improvement in microhardness of the composites when compared to monolithic Mg. From both tensile and compressive test results, enhancement in yield and ultimate strengths were realized in the composites while there was a compromise in failure strain when compared to pure Mg.
Mg/(1 vol Al2O3 + 0.6 vol Cu) exhibited a relatively overall superior hardness, tensile and compressive response.
